description: From Scots buller (“to boil, seethe”). Of obscure origin. Probably related to Old Norse bulla (“to boil”) and Old French bullir (“to boil”), Latin bullio (“I boil”), all from Proto-Indo-European *bew- (“swelling”).

entries.meaning: The bubbling or seething of a torrent.

verbs.description: buller (third-person singular simple present bullers, present participle bullering, simple past and past participle bullered)

description: From Scots buller, bullir (“to bellow, roar”), likely of North Germanic origin, ultimately from Proto-Germanic *bellaną (“to roar”). Compare Danish buldre (“to rumble”), Swedish bullra (“to make a noise, roar, rumble”).

verbs.description: buller (third-person singular simple present bullers, present participle bullering, simple past and past participle bullered)

entries.meaning: To make a lot of noise.
To force one's way; to be pushy.
A steer that allows itself to be mounted by bulls when in the crowded conditions of a feedlot.
